statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Honk, honk: Scott replaces McCants and scores 12
article.linkText: Tar Heels McCan: UNC drops N.C. State, 81-71
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- With the clock winding down in the first half, Melvin Scott got the ball and swished an open 3-pointer just before the buzzer. He had no doubt it was going in; by his count, he's 4-for-4 in that situation this season. "I don't want to toot my own horn, but 'Honk, honk,'" Scott quipped. The senior guard certainly kept his good humor -- and his confidence -- through a rough stretch of games. Stuck on the bench lately in a horrid shooting slump, Scott replaced the ill Rashad McCants in the starting lineup and scored 12 points to lead No. 2 North Carolina past North Carolina State 81-71 on Tuesday night. Raymond Felton had 21 points, seven assists and five rebounds for the Tar Heels (23-3, 11-2), who extended their lead in the Atlantic Coast Conference to a full game over No. 6 Wake Forest. Jawad Williams added 15 points for North Carolina and Sean May and freshman Marvin Williams each scored 14. "I feel great," Scott said. "Everybody was telling me I had to step up, and I answered the challenge." May also had 12 rebounds for his fifth straight double-double, the longest streak for North Carolina since Antawn Jamison in 1998. McCants didn't even make the 25-mile trip because of an intestinal disorder, giving Scott his second start of the season. He had scored only 10 points in his previous four games and was 0-for-8 from 3-point range in that span. Even worse, as one of only three links to the Matt Doherty era, Scott saw his playing time diminish, too. "I decided to start Melvin because he is the most experienced one to start a game on the road," North Carolina coach Roy Williams said. "I also thought it was important for us to have a guy that could make shots." Scott finally did that against the Wolfpack (15-11, 5-8). He finished 4-of-8 on 3s, including two on each side of halftime to give North Carolina a commanding lead. Perhaps inspired by his performance, Scott's teammates also found the range from beyond the arc, finishing 10-of-21. "We didn't do a good job of defending the 3," Wolfpack coach Herb Sendek said. "Give UNC a credit on a job well done." With N.C. State creeping closer in the second half, the Tar Heels made the most of three second-chance opportunities, turning each into 3-pointers to pull away. May rebounded a miss by Felton, then threw a pass back outside, where Felton was stationed behind the line. He swished his jumper to make it 56-50, and after Ilian Evtimov missed a 3 on the other end, Jawad Williams used a screen from Jackie Manuel to get free for an open look from the corner. Finally, when Scott had one of his rare misses, Felton added another 3-pointer for a 12-point lead. N.C. State got no closer than seven the rest of the way. "It's difficult enough to guard them once, let alone twice," Sendek said. Julius Hodge had 20 points on a season-high four 3s for the Wolfpack, who had a modest two-game winning streak snapped. Any hopes of a fourth straight trip to the NCAA tournament likely requires victories in their final three games, including a matchup against Wake Forest to end the season. "I missed a lot of shots around the basket that I usually make," said Hodge, who was 7-for-16 from the field but missed three contested layups. "I did what I usually do when I go to the basket. Sometimes, I was looking for contact and it wasn't there." N.C. State fell behind 49-39 early in the second half before rallying behind freshman Andrew Brackman. He had all eight of his points in a span of about 60 seconds, including a 3-pointer. He capped his personal run by converting a three-point play on a foul by Jawad Williams, and the Wolfpack was within three. Felton then took advantage of an extra opportunity for his 3, and the Tar Heels hung on. "It was difficult to play without Rashad, because he is the leading scorer and is such a threat," Roy Williams said. "We said since we didn't have him, everyone else has to pick up and play well and execute offensively. Engin Atsur had 14 points for N.C. State.
